I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on  (i) a proposed 
loan; and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Republic of Maldives for the South Asia Subregional 
Economic  Cooperation  (SASEC)  National  Single  Window  (NSW)  Project.  The  report  also 
describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for the SASEC NSW Project, and if the Board 
approves the proposed loan and grant, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, 
approve the TA. 
 
2.  The project will leverage information and communication technology (ICT) to improve 
efficiency in cross-border control procedures. It will support the development of an automated 
system that will enable sharing of harmonized data across systems of cross-border regulatory 
agencies (CBRAs),1 Maldives Ports Limited (MPL), and Maldives Airports Company Limited 
(MACL). It will also allow traders and other service providers to submit, and to obtain unified 
clearance of export and import documentation requirements through a single point of entry.  The 
report also describes a TA that will support the Government of Maldives in related capacity 
development of various stakeholders, including on change management. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Overview of the economy. Maldives is one of the smallest countries in Asia and the 
Pacific by population and land area. Its estimated population of 436,330 is widely dispersed over 
188 inhabited islands across an archipelago that is more than 800 kilometers long and 130 
kilometers wide. Despite its geographical challenges, Maldives has successfully developed many 
islands into high-end tourist resorts. Strong growth in the tourism and tourism-related activities 
helped the country attain  upper middle-income status in 2010. However, Maldives’ narrow 
economic  base,  which  is  largely  concentrated  on  tourism,  fisheries,  and  construction,  has 
constrained its growth prospects. 
 
4.  Importance of international trade. Like other small island economies, Maldives relies 
heavily on imports for food, fuel, and capital goods. From 1995 to 2016 imports accounted for 
about 60% of gross domestic product. The value of import transactions increased from about 
$268 million in 1995 to more than $2 billion in 2016. Exports, primarily of fresh fish and processed 
fish products, also increased, from $50 million in 1995 to $140 million in 2016. As a share of gross 
domestic product, however, exports declined from about 11% to about 4% during the same period. 
South Asian countries, especially India and Sri Lanka, are major trading partners of Maldives. As 
such, improving the trade environment of Maldives and promoting digital exchange of information 
among South Asian countries’ customs authorities are expected to result in expanded trade 
among them. 
 
5.  Maldives performance in trade facilitation. Maldives lags on certain trade facilitation 
indicators and has fallen behind in several rankings despite some progress in 2016–2018. In the 
World Bank’s Doing Business 2019 report, Maldives’ rank slipped to 155 in terms of trading across 
borders from 152 in 2018.2 The cost of documentary compliance per export transaction is $300,

Defense. 
2  World Bank Group. 2018. Doing Business 2019: Training  for Reform. Washington, D.C..

2 
among  the  highest  in  South  Asia,  where  the  average  is  $180.  The  cost  of  documentary 
compliance per import transaction is $180. This is lower than the SASEC subregional average of 
$342, but much higher in comparison with Singapore ($40), one of the Asia and Pacific region’s 
benchmarks in terms of trade facilitation. While the time for documentary compliance to export 
(48 hours) and import (61 hours) is lower than the averages for South Asia (77 hours for export 
and 105 hours for import), there is still room for improvement compared with Singapore (2 hours 
for export and 3 hours for import).  
 
6.  Bottlenecks in trade processes. Procedural and organizational bottlenecks substantially 
hamper the efficient flow of trade transactions and increase costs for traders. These bottlenecks 
include (i) paper-based processes, which cause delays and are human resource intensive; (ii) 
underutilization of existing ICT systems in some CBRAs, such as the Maldives Food and Drug 
Authority; (iii) overlapping and redundant documentary requirements, which create unnecessary 
workloads for traders and CBRAs;3 (iv) a physical cargo inspection rate of 100%, which is both 
resource intensive and a source of delays; (v) delays in the release of cargo because of lengthy 
procedures,  space  and  equipment  constraints  at  Malé  commercial  harbor,  and  limited 
infrastructure for security screening of exports at Malé port and airport; and (vi) other procedural 
inefficiencies within CBRAs.4 
 
7.  Actions taken by the government. Through a presidential decree issued in September 
2015, the government formed the National Trade Facilitation Committee (NTFC) to promote 
international trade, including the introduction of an NSW.5  The NTFC has initiated various 
modernization and trade facilitation measures, including (i) online submission and processing of 
customs declarations, (ii) express channels to expedite customs clearance, (iii) a prepayment 
account system and simplified customs declaration for individuals, and (iv) upgrading of goods 
clearance toward a paperless trading environment. In line with its Strategic Plan, 2014–2018,6 and 
following the government’s policy to lower the rate of customs duties in 2012, the Maldives Customs 
Service (MCS) has shifted its focus from tax revenue collection to trade facilitation. New customs 
legislation was also enacted to implement the World Trade Organization (WTO) Customs Valuation 
Agreement.7 
 
8.  National single window road map. An NSW is designed to facilitate and establish an 
efficient international trade environment by reducing delays and lowering costs associated with 
clearance of goods, while maintaining the requisite controls and collection of levies, fees, duties,

3 
and taxes, where applicable, on imports or exports. The NSW road map8 and business process 
redesign (footnote 4) for the NSW in Maldives were prepared to help improve trading across borders. 
The  road  map  defines  the  scope  for  business  process  redesign  of  procedures  and  data 
harmonization among the five CBRAs,  MACL,  and  MPL; and  identifies the legal framework 
requirements and business model options for the NSW operator. The business process redesign 
provides the design for streamlined procedures within the NSW environment. Maldives’ NSW 
development  will  follow  international  standards,  as  embodied  in  the  United  Nations 
recommendations.9 Following common standards is the best way to build interoperability into the 
NSW systems of Maldives and its trading partners.  
 
9.  The project will establish an NSW in Maldives as an electronic platform, which allows 
parties involved in trade and transport to lodge standardized information and documents at a 
single-entry point to fulfill all import- and export-related statutory requirements. The NSW will 
provide an efficient environment for streamlined international trade procedures between private 
sector  stakeholders  and  border  control  agencies.  This  includes  (i)  a  labor-saving  set  of 
standardized and transparent international trade procedures, (ii) enhanced border control, and 
(iii) more readily available data on trade flows. The establishment of the NSW is in line with the 
operational priorities for trade facilitation under the SASEC program. The project will foster 
regional  cooperation  and  integration, strengthen governance  and  institutional  capacity,  and 
promote the use of advanced technologies in line with the priorities of ADB Strategy 2030. 
 
10.  Value added by Asian Development Bank assistance. The Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) has been supporting Maldives in preparing and implementing trade facilitation measures 
through the  conduct  of  seminars  and  studies on  risk management  of  customs’  clearance, 
accession to the Revised Kyoto Convention,10 and the NSW system. As SASEC secretariat, ADB 
organizes the annual meetings of the SASEC customs subgroup, which discuss and plan national 
and subregional initiatives on modernizing customs administrations, among other things. ADB’s 
primary  value  addition  is  founded  on  the  sector  knowledge  gained  through  its  long-term 
engagement in trade facilitation in the SASEC countries. The government recognizes ADB’s good 
record of translating knowledge into effective advisory and analytical inputs to the government’s 
policy  formulation.  Through  its  support  for  SASEC,  ADB  also  brings  the  added  value  of 
complementing country-level assistance to Maldives’ trade facilitation efforts with subregional 
initiatives. Since 2001, the ADB-supported SASEC program has provided a platform for member 
countries to collectively discuss and address trade facilitation issues of subregional concern, 
including those identified in the WTO’s Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA).11 
 
11.  Lessons learned. Challenges in previous NSW implementation in other countries (such 
as India) were related to (i) procurement capability, (ii) project management, and (iii) project 
leadership. Addressing procurement and project implementation challenges is crucial since the 
NSW environment requires integration of the NSW system with multiple stakeholders and their

parallel projects across different organizations. In the context of the project, supervision is also 
important given the project’s broad scope, and the risks of misalignment with desired deliverables. 
There  is  a  need for a project champion  to  effectively  mobilize  the  multiple  ministries  and 
government agencies. Incorporating these lessons, ADB will assist the government to implement 
institutional reform by providing support for change management through the attached TA. 
 
B.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
12.  The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) efficient international trade facilitation 
ensured;12 and (ii) faster, cheaper, and more predictable cross-border trade in the SASEC 
subregion achieved.13 The project will have the following outcome: efficiency in cargo clearance 
improved.14 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
13.  Output 1: National single window system for international trade and reengineered 
trade processes established. The nationwide online system that provides for all relevant parties 
to submit standardized information at a single-entry point to fulfill all import, export, and transit-
related regulatory requirements will be established in two phases. In the first phase, systems of 
the agencies which show high readiness,15 will be interfaced with the NSW system. The systems 
of the rest of the CBRAs will be connected in the second phase. The capacity building for 
operation and maintenance will be provided under the project. Business processes reengineering 
measures to streamline international procedures will be implemented. By project completion in 
2023, the local NSW operator will be fully responsible for operations of the NSW. 
 
14.  Output 2: Capacity of relevant agencies and private sector users, including women, 
to utilize the national single window developed. This output will be financed by the TA and 
includes (i) supporting the government in finalizing the NSW framework and e-transaction bill, (ii) 
developing and implementing a change management strategy, capacity development plan, and 
NSW operations manual to increase buy-in and capacity of CBRAs and other relevant agencies 
to utilize the NSW; and (iii) outreach to private sectors, including women in inner and outer atolls.  
The NSW Operator will also set up a helpdesk to assist NSW users. 
  
15.  Output 3: High-level technologies to support national single window and trade 
facilitation pilot tested. This output will be financed by the TA and includes pilot testing the 
application of blockchain, a high-level technology that enables users to track shipping items and 
record all related documentation history on its distributed ledger without a chance of falsification. 
Blockchain has the potential to be adopted as the future operating system of the NSW system. 
An e-payment gateway platform—a component of the NSW to be connected to e-payment 
systems—functions as a hub and simplifies the processing of payment transactions for electronic 
services. The project will disseminate pilot-testing results, raise awareness, and build knowledge 
and capacity of the officials of all agencies related to the NSW system, to familiarize them with 
relevant blockchain and e-payment applications.

III.  ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
22.  The proposed transaction TA attached to the project will (i) support the government to 
finalize legal framework required for effective implementation of the NSW system, (ii) develop and 
monitor  project  design  and  implementation  requirements,  (iii)  conduct  capacity  building  to 
implement and operate the NSW system, and (iv) pilot test high-level technologies for sustainable 
development of the NSW system.18 The TA is estimated to cost $1.1 million, of which (i) $0.5 
million will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6); 
and (ii) $0.5 million will be financed on a grant basis by the High-Level Technology Fund19 and 
administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, office 
space, and other in-kind contributions. The implementation period will be from June 2019 to June 
2023 and the executing agency will be the MOF. ADB will handle the administration of the TA. 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
23.  Technical due diligence confirmed that designs are robust and sustainable and included 
a comprehensive review of the project feasibility study, system designs, and cost estimates. 
Technical aspects of the project were appraised based on (i) rationale and relevance, benefits, 
proposed  designs,  and  ease  of  implementation  and  operations;  (ii)  a  range  of  technical 
alternatives and their viability along with least-cost analysis; (iii) the life cycle costs, including 
capital and operating costs, and achievable cost savings; (iv) maximization of beneficiary area 
coverage including the poor; and (v) optimization of timelines for implementation through high 
project readiness. NSW objectives and effectiveness act as a catalyst toward comprehensive 
streamlining of procedures by CBRAs and automated processing. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
24.  The analysis was prepared using a cost–benefit analysis approach in accordance with 
ADB guidelines. 20 The main project benefits are time and resource savings. Benefits arise from 
streamlined business processes that reduce time spent on processing trade documents and their 
associated costs, including reproduction, storage, archiving, filing, and processing. Time savings 
to traders and CBRAs are derived from less frequent visits to CBRAs, including queueing at 
application and payment windows. Importers, forwarders, and goods processors would spend 
less time for cargo release and travel costs associated with these tasks. Benefits also derive from 
other avoided costs involving stakeholder transport and travel, and lost time to other productive 
endeavors and leisure. Reduced time and cost are also likely to increase trade volumes. 
 
25.  Economic costs are derived from financial costs using shadow exchange rate factors. 
Using a social discount rate of 9%, the project has a mean economic net present value of $3.57 
million and a mean economic internal rate of return of 13.6%. These benefits, combined with 
unquantifiable benefits will more than compensate for the overall cost attributed to the project. 
Risk analysis using a Monte Carlo simulation model was used to account for project risks and 
uncertainties.21 The results showed a probability of less than 15% that the project would not 
achieve the ADB standard economic opportunity cost of capital of 9%.

C.  Governance 
 
26.  Financial management. The financial management risk of the project is rated substantial. 
However, based on the financial management assessment, MED’s overall financial management 
arrangements are adequate to implement the project with the proposed mitigation measures. In 
addition, the MED is already familiar with ADB’s disbursement procedures since it served as the 
implementing agency for the Inclusive Micro, Small, and Medium-Sized Enterprise Development 
Project.22 A project monitoring unit will be established under the MED. 
 
27.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  MOF.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 15). The government has been informed of ADB’s 
public disclosure requirement on audited project financial statements. 
 
D.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
28.  Poverty. Overall poverty of 7.3% (2009) along with widening income inequality and 
unemployment is still a major issue in Maldives.23 The implementation of an NSW is estimated to 
generate $17 million annual savings for both the government and the private sector through lower 
transaction costs.24 These additional resources can be utilized for better provision of, and greater 
access to, public services serving a bigger segment of the population, particularly those in the 
outer atolls where poverty incidence is high. The NSW will also reduce the overall costs of 
transactions by cutting retail prices of imported staple goods, such as food and fuel, thereby 
benefiting consumers, especially low-income people. In addition, the project will strengthen and 
improve the ease of doing business environment and facilitate private sector development, which 
are deemed crucial for employment creation and economic growth. 
 
29.  Gender. The project is categorized some gender elements. Women’s participation in trade 
and other economic fields remains low in Maldives because of, among other things, geographic 
dispersion, traditions, customs, and the institutional environment. While an NSW will not address 
this directly, it will support creating a women-friendly environment to improve their access to trade-
related services. An NSW will help women traders and entrepreneurs to effectively use their time 
in managing both business and domestic responsibilities. An NSW will also espouse a gender-
neutral environment since the CBRAs and the NSW operator will be bound by service-level 
agreements that will require them to deliver and perform within an expected level of performance 
for all clients regardless of gender. 
 
E.  Safeguards

categories are as follows.25

31.  Environment (category C). The project has no adverse environmental impacts. Servers 
and computers will be installed in existing government facilities with negligible impact on the 
environment. No civil works will be implemented. The MOF and its implementing agencies will 
ensure compliance with national regulations on disposal of ICT equipment. 
 
32.  Involuntary  resettlement  (category  C).  The  project  will  not  result  in  involuntary 
resettlement because of full or partial and/or permanent or temporary physical displacement and 
economic  displacement  resulting  from  (i)  involuntary  acquisition  of  land  or  (ii)  involuntary 
restrictions on land use or access to legally designated parks and protected areas. Servers and 
computers will be installed within existing government facilities. 
 
33.  Indigenous peoples (category C). There are no indigenous people communities present 
at or around the project site.

V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
35.  The government and the MOF have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform  to  all  related  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and financing documents. 
 
                                                
26  Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

36.  The government and the MOF have agreed with ADB on certain conditions and covenants 
for the project, which are set forth in the draft loan and grant agreements. It will be a condition to 
effectiveness of the loan and grant agreements that the government will have formally established 
the operator of the NSW, and such operator will have commenced functioning to an extent 
acceptable to ADB. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
37.  I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  loan  and  grant  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the loan of $5,000,000 to the Republic of Maldives for the South Asia Subregional 
Economic Cooperation National Single Window Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources, in concessional terms, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per year 
during the grace period and 1.5% per year thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including 
a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially 
in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the 
Board; and 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding $5,000,000 to the Republic of Maldives, from ADB’s Special 
Funds  resources  (Asian  Development  Fund),  for  the  South  Asia  Subregional 
Economic Cooperation National Single Window Project, on terms and conditions that 
are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement 
presented to the Board.
